awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a flow cytometer to promote microbe-focused research, training, and teaching at NC State University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to North Carolina State University (NCSU) to purchase a cytometer for fluorescence activated cell sorting (FACS).  The acquisition will support new (e.g., Single-cell Technologies) and revamped (e.g., Immunology and High-Throughput Discovery) teaching modules within NCSU's Biotechnology (BIT) program, whose primary goal is to educate and train undergraduate and graduate students in areas of biotechnology. Courses outside BIT will also be supported; the cytometer will enable more modern labs/instruction in undergraduate Genetics, as well as in various environmental microbiology areas (e.g., Aquatic Microbiology, Biological Oceanography, Estuary Biogeochemistry). Cumulatively, >350 students are anticipated to gain experience with flow cytometry technology through these courses. More than 25 graduate students and postdoctoral scholars will gain direct experience with FACS through NCSU research projects utilizing the system. To increase awareness of FACS (and flow cytometry in general) technology among underrepresented undergraduates in the Raleigh, NC, area, FACS & Flow Cytometry workshops will be conducted annually for 4 years. The participants in these workshops will make presentations at the NC Museum of Natural Science to convey their resulting scientific literacy and knowledge to the general public.


The award is heavily devoted to promoting diverse scientific research programs at NCSU, as well as at neighboring universities.  Areas of scientific research that will be supported include: aquatic plankton ecology, harmful algal bloom ecology, detection of pollutant degrading bacteria, extremophile microbial ecology, symbiosis, rapid antibiotic and enzyme discovery, genetic identification of dinosaur cells, and bivalve nutrition and microbiomes. At NCSU alone, these research groups represent four colleges and extensive support from current research awards. All results from the research enabled by the FACS system will be disseminated in reputable peer-reviewed publications and at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A user-friendly fluorescence activated cell sorting (FACS) flow cytometer (BD FACSMelody) was acquired and installed as part of a new facility at NC State University (NCSU), the MicroFACS facility on main campus (https://microfacs.wordpress.ncsu.edu/).  The instrument and facility serve researchers and teachers whose work or educational programs focus on non-mammalian microbes.  This is a unique resource within the Research Triangle of North Carolina where most sorting flow cytometry facilities do not allow sorting of samples that contain bacteria/prokaryotes and/or require a technician?s assistance. Undergraduates, graduates, post docs, faculty, and employees from universities, non-profits, and consulting firms used the FACSMelody to advance their research or teaching programs at NCSU.  During the three year grant period, 20 different persons were frequent users of the instrument, >50 persons were trained on the instrument or consulted in regard to their specific research needs, and >50 undergraduates and graduate students gained first-hand experience with the instrument through three different NC State University Biotechnology (BIT) and Aquatic/Marine science courses. Diverse research was advanced via use of the FACSMelody, including: the development of E. coli GFP-based biosensor systems, GFP-tracking of infected cells, microbial directed evolution, chemical engineering of antibiotics, marine plankton nitrogen cycling, cyanobacterial ecology, cell nanobead labeling, bioprospecting metagenomes for genes/organism beneficial to plant roots, and cultivation of bloom forming cyanobacteria from San Francisco Bay.

Broader impacts resulting from acquisition of the FACSMelody include: 1) establishment of a flow cytometry facility (MicroFACS) on NCSU main campus that specifically promotes microbial research/teaching and has pledged future support by NCSU, 2) exposure of >50 undergraduate students to FACS/flow cytometry through NCSU courses mentioned above, 3) a flow cytometry and FACS workshop was held conveying basic principles and provided resources primarily to students/staff/faculty from Research Triangle area HBCUs (based on pre/post questionnaires the attendees improved their knowledge significantly based on twice as many correct answers related to flow cytometry), and 4) remote Zoom presentations (during pandemic lockdown) reached an estimated student audience of 100 students - specifically perspective undergraduates (Agriculture Discovery Program 2021), and members of NCSU campus undergraduate clubs (Biology, BIT).  A professional-grade user tutorial video was developed to serve as a remote resource for users and students, and was published on YouTube https://youtu.be/hw5KvEbM_C4 and via the MicroFACS website. Last, a virtual Map of the facility and FACSMelody was created and archived with support from the NCSU Delta Grant program: https://go.ncsu.edu/microfacs-scan. This resource has utility in the future for distance learning - providing a more engaging learning experience for students, but also as a general teaching tool for in-person courses and large classes.
